overview.short: Spirillum serpens is a Gram-negative, aerobic spiral-shaped bacterium commonly found in freshwater and soil environments.
overview.clinical_context: Primarily environmental; rarely associated with human disease and typically identified incidentally.

species_markers.notes: True spiral morphology with rigid coils distinguishes S. serpens from curved rods.
Supports classification among oxidase-positive environmental spirals.

common_confusions.reason: Both may appear curved or spiral; Campylobacter is microaerophilic and grows best at higher temperatures.
Spiral morphology overlap; Helicobacter is usually urease-positive and microaerophilic.

when_to_question_identification: Growth under microaerophilic rather than aerobic conditions suggests Campylobacter or Helicobacter.
Any carbohydrate fermentation profile argues against S. serpens.
Clinical relevance should be questioned without strong environmental exposure history.

recommended_next_tests.reason: Confirms spiral shape and characteristic polar motility.
Useful for documenting non-fermentative biochemical profile.
Recommended due to rarity and limited biochemical resolution.
